s.text: The rumor of a Senate run seems dead, but a local satirical revue proposes that Clinton capitalize on his legendary press-the-flesh skill by working as a Wal-Mart greeter.
The rumor of a Senate run seems dead, but a local satirical revue proposes that Clinton capitalize on his legendary press-the-flesh skill by working as a Wal-Mart greeter.
The rumor of a Senate run seems dead, but a local satirical revue proposes that Clinton capitalize on his legendary press-the-flesh skill by working as a Wal-Mart greeter.
City officials are incredibly sensitive to the charge that they are buying Clinton land with money that should go to feeding the giraffes.
All this time, the land for the library has sat undisturbed, covered with tall weeds and empty buildings, its intended purpose marked only by a banner that has grown progressively more tattered.
They hit upon the idea of issuing "parks revenue bonds," which didn't require voter approval, and pledging revenues from the city's golf courses, parks, and zoo to pay them down.
And after recovering from the initial euphoria over winning the big prize, Mayor Jim Dailey and Co. realized they had to find $15 million to buy and clear the property.
For reasons too Byzantine to explain, it's the only unaccredited big zoo in the nation, and it could use a cash infusion.
For reasons too Byzantine to explain, it's the only unaccredited big zoo in the nation, and it could use a cash infusion.
For reasons too Byzantine to explain, it's the only unaccredited big zoo in the nation, and it could use a cash infusion.
For reasons too Byzantine to explain, it's the only unaccredited big zoo in the nation, and it could use a cash infusion.
Even some Clinton fans have a bad taste in their mouths about the way the Little Rock board of directors arranged to pay for the 28-acre site.

But the city board eventually compromised, renaming just the few blocks of Markham Street around the library after the president--a plan the mayor said he came to embrace after asking himself, "What would Jesus do?"
When the city's newly hired zoo director came to town for a meet-and-greet recently, reporters were warned in no uncertain terms that he was not to be asked about the library.)
